Award.AwardTitle: An Ecological Assessment of New York's Home Buyout Program: Exploring Lived Experiences and Implications for Affected Households and Communities

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
After a natural disaster, residents may find their homes damaged or destroyed. When this happens, they sometimes choose or are forced to permanently move to new communities. In some cases people relocate with help from home buyout programs, which allow homeowners to sell their homes to the state. By moving residents out of areas that are at risk for disasters, buyout programs may improve the safety, health, and well-being of communities. They may also guard against expensive losses from future disasters. But as of now, it is not clear if buyout programs reduce risk or improve the well-being of residents in the long run. There may even be negative consequences for residents who participate in a buyout program. For example, moving away from your community, friends, and family can be stressful, and can have long-term social and health consequences. Because more communities in areas that are at risk for floods, hurricanes, and other disasters will be faced with relocation decisions, it will be important to make the process as effective and efficient as possible. By comparing how residents were affected by a home buyout program in three communities in New York after Hurricane Sandy, this research project will create new knowledge about how home buyout programs impact people and communities over time. Results will be used to develop recommendations for how these programs can protect communities, aid in the recovery process, and make communities more resilient to disasters and other crises. This project will move the field forward by supporting and training students and early career researchers in disaster policy and planning. Results and recommendations will be shared with communities, researchers, and policymakers.

Using an ecological, comparative approach, this research project employs mixed-methods to explore processes and impacts related to home buyouts over time and at multiple levels. Residents of three communities with distinctive buyout experiences (one community where most residents chose to accept a buyout, one where most chose to reject a buyout, and one non-participating community adjacent to the relocated community) will be invited to participate. Specifically, this project will examine three key dimensions of the post-disaster home buyout experience: heterogeneity of buyout decision-making within communities, lived experiences of relocation and rebuilding over time, and secondary impacts of buyouts on affected, non-participating households and communities. Participants will be asked to complete in-depth interviews (designed to gather data on the lived experiences and perceived impacts of the buyout or rebuilding process) and surveys (designed to examine indicators related to social capital and place attachment comparatively and longitudinally). Data will be analyzed to examine with whom and in what contexts home buyout programs are beneficial. Results will inform current theory on post-disaster relocation and contribute to the development and implementation of effective buyout policies and programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Home buyout programs facilitate the permanent relocation of residents away from areas that are at risk from future hazards, and they are an important policy tool for climate change adaptation. In the wake of Hurricane Sandy in 2012, New York implemented a home buyout program in several coastal communities as part of a disaster mitigation and recovery effort.

Based on New York's buyout program, this longitudinal study was the first to systematically assess the impacts of buyouts into the mid- and long-term recovery period, and the first to examine the impacts of buyouts on neighboring communities. We followed cohorts from three communities for over five years, with each community following a distinctive recovery pathway. As of 2014, there were no significant differences between the study communities on key measures of community well-being, making them ideal for a comparative study. Over a five-year period, however, participant outcomes fluctuated by neighborhood of origin on several recovery indicators, including social capital, place attachment, perceived risk, and self-reported health.

The primary study community, Oakwood Beach, was included in the buyout program, and nearly all residents opted to participate in the buyout and relocate. The process of relocation, which lasted for more than two years, in many cases, was associated with a suite of negative impacts, including significant losses in place attachment and social capital. Three years post-disaster, buyout participants were faring worse than residents of the two comparison communities, as indicated by relatively lower levels of bonding social capital (implying unrestored losses in their close social networks), place dependence (implying that their new homes and communities are not equally meeting their needs), and place identity (implying that they have not yet developed an emotional attachment to their new homes or communities). After five years, these impacts began to lessen, with buyout participants beginning to form attachments to their new neighbors and community and showing improvements in mental health. Importantly, one in five buyout participants from Staten Island relocated to areas at equal or greater risk to flood hazards, calling into question of the efficacy of buyouts in reducing hazard risk.

The second study community, Rockaway Park, was initially included in the study as a comparison site, as most residents of Rockaway Park immediately rejected the idea of a buyout and chose to rebuild in place instead. Residents of Rockaway Park consistently exhibited better recovery outcomes than the other two communities, though five years post-Sandy, participants described changes to their community that were not positive, including areas of disrepair, overcrowding from additional traffic, and critical services (e.g., hospital) that never reopened. While participants continued to report increases in their levels of place identify, their bonding with neighbors began decreasing, as did their physical health.

The third study community, which we will refer to as the peripheral community, is located adjacent to Oakwood Beach. The peripheral community was excluded from the buyout program, but still directly impacted by it as their immediate neighbors relocated and they experienced the demolition of the neighboring community. Over time, the buyout negatively impacted their community and individual well-being. After three years, residents maintained a level of place identity greater than relocated residents of Oakwood Beach but significantly lower than Rockaway. At the same time, they reported an increase in perception of risk from hurricanes and floods, likely influenced from the state-sponsored relocation of their immediate neighbors, whose homes were deemed to be at significant risk from future hazards. After five years, the peripheral community showed a consistent decline, as indicated by losses in social capital and place attachment, in addition to greater perceived risk of hurricanes, floods, and crime compared to residents of the other communities. Residents also experienced a decline in both physical and mental health, along with experiencing the highest stress and lowest satisfaction with life among the three communities.

Taken together, findings from this study suggest that the social costs of buyouts extend well into the recovery period and radiate to communities surrounding the buyout zone. Over the course of five years, buyout participants were able to make progress toward returning to pre-disaster levels of well-being. However, relocated residents still fared consistently worse on recovery measures than residents who rebuilt in place, and qualitative data suggests that buyout participants continued to experience significant strain associated with the relocation. Many relocated to areas of equal or greater risk, influenced by complex social and economic factors. The impacts on the peripheral community, which showed a consistent decline across the five-year study period, indicate that much more research is needed on the impacts of buyouts on affected, non-participating communities.

This study engaged 19 undergraduates, 7 post-baccalaureates, and 1 graduate student, 25 of whom were members of underrepresented groups within STEM disciplines. It produced 6 academic publications, a policy white paper on home buyout best practices, and 21 academic presentations.
